Smaller regional GEO operators are concerned about picking the right partner for multi-orbit strategies, as building their own constellations is not financially feasible. They are looking for partnerships with mega-constellation companies to resell their capacity and fill service gaps.

To complement or remedy the lack of an existing GEO network, private operators as well as the ESA also develop their own Data Relay Satellite Systems (EDRS), aka Inter-Satellite Data Relay System (IDRS).

Data relay satellites are placed in geostationary orbit to relay information to and from non-geostationary satellites, spacecraft, other vehicles and fixed Earth stations that otherwise are not able to permanently transmit/receive data, contributing to a network that is fast, reliable and seamless.

6.2. Antenna technology

6.2.1. Phased Array Antennas

Phased Array antennas represent a significant leap in antenna technology, particularly for satellite systems. Unlike traditional antennas that radiate energy in a fixed direction, phased arrays consist of multiple individual elements, each of which can be controlled independently. This allows for the electronic steering of the antenna’s radiation pattern without physically moving the structure, offering rapid direction change and the ability to focus signals more precisely.

The core principle behind phased arrays is the constructive and destructive interference of waves. By carefully adjusting the phase of each antenna element, the array can create a beam that is highly directional. This is incredibly useful for radar systems that require quick scanning across large areas, as well as for satellite communication where a narrow beam can minimize interference and enhance data throughput. As technology advances, the size and cost of these arrays continue to decrease, making them increasingly accessible for a wider range of applications.

Thanks to their adaptive capabilities, phased array antennas enable more advanced spectrum sharing scenarios among various users and applications, which may result eventually in more flexible spectrum allocation in the future.

6.2.2. MIMO (Multiple Input, Multiple Output)

Multiple-Input, Multiple-Output (MIMO) technology is a groundbreaking innovation in wireless communication that uses multiple antennas at both the transmitter and receiver ends to improve performance. By employing several antennas rather than a single one, MIMO significantly enhances data rates and spectrum efficiency without requiring additional bandwidth or power. Essentially, it turns the challenges posed by multipath signal propagation -often a source of interference and fading- into an advantage by treating each signal path as a separate channel that can transmit additional data. This is akin to adding more lanes on a highway, allowing for more cars -or in this case, data- to be transmitted in parallel. Advanced signal processing algorithms at the receiver end decode these multiple streams, separating them into the original data.

Predominantly used for terrestrial networks such as 4G, 5G and Wi-Fi protocols, MIMO technology starts to be investigated for satellite communications too . Although MIMO can lead to more efficient spectrum utilization, its ability to simultaneously transmit and receive multiple data streams may introduce complexity to satellite radio regulations and necessitate revisited guidelines to manage coexistence with other satellite and terrestrial services.

6.3. Communication technology

6.3.1. ISL (Inter Satellite Link)

Inter-Satellite Link (ISL) is a technology that allows satellites to communicate directly with each other without having to route signals through a ground station first. Traditionally, communication between satellites involved sending data down to a ground station, which would then relay it to another satellite. This indirect routing can introduce latency and requires robust ground infrastructure.

ISLs, on the other hand, enable a more direct and faster form of communication between satellites. This is especially useful for constellations in LEO or MEO, where frequent handovers between satellites are needed to maintain continuous coverage. ISLs improve the efficiency of data transmission by reducing the time and energy it takes to send data from one point to another.

ISLs can be established through either radio frequencies or optical means (see next section). Radio frequency ISLs are more traditional and have lower data rates, but they are generally more robust against atmospheric conditions. Commonly used frequency bands include Ka-band (26.5-40 GHz), Ku-band (12-18 GHz) and the V-band (40–75 GHz) . Optical ISLs, on the other hand, can offer higher data rates and lower power consumption but are more susceptible to interference from atmospheric conditions like clouds.

Besides reducing latency, ISLs also increase the redundancy and resilience of the satellite network. In the event that a ground station fails or experiences downtime, satellites can use ISLs to reroute data through other satellites to reach its destination, making the whole communication network more robust and fault-tolerant.

As satellite constellations grow in size and complexity, especially with the advent of mega-constellations like SpaceX’s Starlink or OneWeb, the role of ISLs is expected to become increasingly critical for maintaining high levels of performance and reliability in satellite communications. Agenda Item 1.17 of WRC-23 precisely discussed new ISL service allocation in specific frequency bands.

6.3.2. Optical communications

Instead of traditional radio frequency communications, satellite optical communications make use of laser light to transmit data from Earth to Space or Space to Space (ISL), offering a significant leap in terms of data throughput .

Conventional encryption is facing an increasing risk of being compromised as hacking techniques evolve, in particular due to the emergence of quantum computing. This is where QKD (commonly known as Quantum Cryptography) technology comes into play by making it possible for operators to encrypt data in such a way that it remains immune to future attacks by quantum computers.

QKD uses quantum properties of photons, the elementary particles of light, to encrypt secret keys that can be shared by two parties to protect their communications. The technique, deemed unhackable since any attempt to eavesdrop on the communication changes the state of the photons and destroys the keys, is already proven in fiber optic networks and starts to be experimented for satellite communications.

As part of the European Quantum Communication Initiative (EuroQCI) , the European Commission is currently working with ESA on the specifications of a first constellation of EuroQCI satellites. It will build on the first prototype satellite Eagle1, developed by ESA and an industrial consortium, and due to be launched in late 2024. The ESA is also working on the Quantum Key Distribution Satellite (QKDSat) project to demonstrate how a space-based quantum infrastructure can be used to keep secure the exchange of sensitive information between several parties.

The introduction of QKD encryption in satellite communications could require updates in regulations to address specific spectrum allocations for quantum signals, manage interferences to ensure the integrity of quantum states, and develop standards to safeguard quantum-based transmissions from eavesdropping or other forms of intrusion.

6.3.4. SDR (Software Defined Radio)

Software Defined Radio (SDR) has become increasingly integral to satellite communications, serving as a transformative technology that shifts much of the signal processing from hardware to software. This shift allows for unprecedented flexibility in communications, for both ground stations and in-orbit satellites. In traditional hardware-based systems, modifying the functionality often requires physical changes to the equipment. With SDR, adjustments can be made via software updates, making it far easier to adapt to new communication protocols, data rates, or encryption methods.

One of the significant benefits is the ability to reconfigure the satellite’s communication systems while it is already in orbit. As technology and needs evolve on Earth, the satellite and the ground stations can evolve along with them .

6.4. Ground segment

6.4.1. Ground Station as a Service

The business model of Satellite Ground Station as a Service (GSaaS) operates on a subscription or pay-as-you-go basis, offering users access to ground station infrastructure without the need to build and maintain their own facilities. This model is highly scalable, providing services that range from data downlinking to command and control functionalities for satellites. Companies or governmental agencies in need of satellite communication services can simply rent time or bandwidth on these ground stations. This significantly reduces the barriers to entry for smaller companies or research institutions that may not have the capital to invest in complex ground station infrastructure.

The GSaaS provider manages the operational complexities such as maintenance, software updates, and regulatory compliance, allowing the customer to focus on its core mission.

There is a distinction between suppliers that own their ground stations, and therefore handle the regulatory authorizations (e.g. LeafSpace, KSAT) and those relying upon networks of ground stations built by traditional space companies (e.g. Amazon Web Services, Microsoft) .

6.4.2. Low-cost user terminals

The cost of end-user satellite terminals has been decreasing over the past few years, primarily due to advancements in technology and increasing economies of scale. As the satellite industry grows, more manufacturers are entering the market, contributing to a reduction in component costs. Innovations in miniaturization have also led to smaller, more efficient terminals that are less expensive to produce.

Companies are starting to adopt a consumer-oriented approach, designing user-friendly terminals that can be self-installed, thus eliminating the need for professional installation services and their associated costs. This trend is making satellite communication more accessible to the general public.

The proliferation of cheaper and more abundant user terminals can have several implications for satellite radio regulations:

• Increased interference potential: With more devices accessing the spectrum, there’s a higher risk of interference, necessitating stricter spectrum management and coordination;

• Licensing challenges: The sheer volume of devices could complicate licensing processes, potentially pushing regulatory bodies to adopt blanket licensing or streamline licensing procedures for user terminals;

• Enhanced demand for spectrum: A surge in user terminals can lead to increased demand for available spectrum bands, requiring adjustments in allocation and sharing strategies;

• Security concerns: A greater number of devices, especially if they’re more affordable and potentially less secure, can introduce vulnerabilities in the communication network, prompting regulatory measures to reinforce security standards.

7. Recommended practices

As seen in previous sections, the regulatory landscape around satellite telecommunications, and in particular NGSO constellations involves multiple stakeholders, each holding distinct roles and responsibilities. Crafting a regulatory environment that is both supportive of technological advancements and protective of diverse interests demands a delicate balancing act. The following examples shed light on some good practices and recommendations that can help streamline efforts towards a more sustainable use of outer space.

For regulators

Efficient spectrum use remains a priority area for regulators, especially as telecommunications and satellite communications converge , demanding strategic decisions and coordinated international efforts to support satellite broadband operations.

The complexity and swift progression of space technologies require cautious regulatory approaches possibly emulating the ITU model of utilizing general, and at times legally binding, treaties as foundational guidelines, with subsequent periodic updates to keep pace with technological innovations.

While doing this, it is fundamental to foster international harmonization of spectrum allocations, adhere to ITU Radio Regulations, and ensure timely and fair adjustments of policies to cope with technological and operational constraints of operators .

Furthermore, promoting the deployment of innovative technologies while maintaining technologically neutral goals, and fostering international cooperation on anti-competitive behaviors ensures that the regulatory ecosystem promotes innovation while safeguarding equitable and efficient spectrum use .

In some specific cases, where traditional satellite service operations would require the establishment of a local Earth Station enabling legal intercept, regulators are encouraged to develop innovative approaches that would suit better the requirements of NGSO global constellations that by design require a multitude of Earth Stations for their operations, and therefore cannot route all traffic through a single Ground Station. A possible way forward could be the conditioning of licenses to a commitment from operators to provide remote access to information if required by national enforcement agencies.

With a similar objective to ease the market entry of new NGSO satellite operators, regulators are encouraged to tailor licensing fees to the business model of satellite services. For example, it may be challenging for satellite narrowband operators to afford sometimes expensive one-off upfront licensing fees to access a market, especially when their business model fundamentally relies on ultra-low-cost communications and the deployment of a large number of assets. These are resources they may lack upon entering the market.

For international organizations

In the document published for the 2022 IAC, ITU outlines key areas for strengthening governance in space activities:

• Fostering an international harmonization of binding rules, such as those related to debris management, to reinforce the responsibilities of space actors. This could be done by including sustainable use of spectrum and orbital resources in the Radio Regulations (RR);

• Enhancing liaison between stakeholders at various levels, citing ITU conferences and study groups as effective negotiation platforms. Investing in these liaisons, despite the costs and complexities, will lead to more consensual decisions, better knowledge flow, and improved synergies among stakeholder groups.

For operators

In a context necessitating adoption of more sustainable behaviors for space activities, and lacking legally binding rules, it is important to provide operators with guidelines and best practices for designing their space missions.

As highlighted in previous sections, significant progress has been made, enabling operators to rely on both international and national guidelines. These guidelines require regular updates to stay aligned with the new applications introduced by NewSpace. For example, ITU recommendations for the disposal of GEO satellites at the end of their lifecycle should also be extended to NGSO satellites.

Besides, the large number of recommendations from various institutions available to satellite operators, may appear overwhelming to newcomers in terms of their sheer number and level of technical detail. To overcome this and promote the inclusion of newcomers and smaller players, alternative communication means such as video tutorials might be considered.
